Key Arguments: The definitions of misinformation and disinformation in the bill are vague and overly broad.
The bill grants excessive power to ACMA, potentially infringing on free speech and democratic principles.
Existing legislation is sufficient for controlling harmful information in emergencies.
The bill could lead to censorship and state control over digital platforms, akin to totalitarian regimes.
The bill lacks adequate checks and balances and does not protect independent journalism.
The proposed measures infantilize the public by implying they cannot discern truth from falsehood.
The bill could stifle dissent and limit the public's ability to challenge government narratives.
Notable Quotes: By imposing regulations and penalties on platform providers to implement censorship and sanctions on users depends on them to correctly interpret those regulations in any given circumstance and effectively co-opts them as state sponsored thought police.

A Government that fears dissent is obviously trying to do something which is, by definition, something they would rather the public not know about, and therefore the precise reason the public should know.
This bill is an abomination and if it is to pass, it will see the descent of this great nation into fascism the likes of which even Stalin and Mao could not conceive of in their wildest dreams.
